Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @jl777c even if we somehow only burned 1sat every *other* transaction, I think that would still make the analysis harder. There could be a trade-off with how often 1sat burns are sent.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <denio> And it was way more then a small gpu farm üòÇ

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <gigamesh> if yes how does he find the z addresses to send to?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @gigamesh not quite

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> he is not sending dust

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> that is where the confusion starts

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> He is figuring out which transactions depend on which others

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> By trying to replay/simulate history, and doing it out-of-order

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> If I replay history, but leave out TX1 and replay TX2, and TX2 still works, that means TX2 did not depend on TX1

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> This leaks metadata

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> now you do this for the entire history, every possible way

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> and so much data falls out, it's scary

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> nobody has really thought about this, I say @ITM invented it

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> @dukeleto deanonimization mostly about tracing the transaction graphs, the issue with zaddrs was that it was not known how to do it, until the "ITM" attack

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> right, it's trivial with taddrs

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> ITM, he likes to think in reverse

Author: Gateway#3763

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> dusting attacks on XMR have a long and illustrious history

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> but this new ITM attack, it's a new class of analysis

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> I keep calling it an attack , but maybe that is confusing for people. It's an attack on metadata

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> but really, it's just analyzing the public blockchain

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> I consider it an attack, that zaddrs can drip out so much metadata

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @passcombo.com üè¥‚ò†üçã the purpose of HushList is to run on many chains

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Pirate and Hush will both react to this new attack, as best we can. Most chains will do nothing

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Since Pirate and Hush have different consensus rules about taddrs, analysis will be different on each chain, and studying things on both chains gives us a lot of data

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Burning 1sat in every zaddr xtn might become the new super-shielded-xtn

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> without an unspendable zaddr output, you are vulnerable anytime in the future to a @ITM attack

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> this changes a lot of what we know about zcash protocol coins

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> TLDR: Do not give out your zaddrs publicly, do not give out txids publicly! Unless absolutely needed! It reduces the privacy of zaddrs for people to know that info about you.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Use one zaddr for public use, is a good opsec. Never give out any others publicly

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> we call this an "introducer" in HushList

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> radix42 predicted all this years ago, by making this part of the hushlist protocol. You only give out 1 zaddr publicly

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> there is no good way to tell wallet.dat that some outputs shouldn't be spent

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @jl777c since i wrote the ZIP/HIP/KIP about wallet.dat, I feel comfortable potentially modifying it

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> we could make the wallet not spend some outputs

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> it would be backward compatible

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> not a consensus change

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> just add a tag of data to some xtns

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> and choose not to spend those, ever

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> maybe only with some CLI flag

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> "this dust protects your privacy"

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> destroy when done using it

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Just some thoughts, but there is some beef there.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <actionslacks> in dust we trust

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <actionslacks> exciting stuff. this has some serious implications.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <mrlynch> @dukeleto provably unspendable addresses seem to be the solution

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <mrlynch> from your zcash experience, instead of pubkey, is it the diversifier that needs to be invalid?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> https://tenor.com/view/why-not-both-gif-11478682

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> burn 1sat xtns, or tag unspendable xtns locally. Both options are good.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <mrlynch> because we go back to giving users the option of protecting their privacy which, history dictates that they won't due to comfort/cutting corners

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> that makes the analysis harder, still. Because we have multiple options

Author: Gateway#3763

Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Let's say that. It's good for investors, because this will reduce circulating supply that is actually spendable

Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> and more z adoption => more burning
